content.title: Hypothenar Hammer Syndrome
content.definition: Occupational vascular disorder caused by repetitive blunt trauma to the hypothenar eminence, resulting in injury to the ulnar artery as it crosses the hamate bone. Leads to thrombosis, aneurysm formation, or embolization causing digital ischemia in the ulnar artery distribution.

key_concepts.description: Ulnar artery is vulnerable where it crosses the hook of hamate superficially (Guyon's canal); repetitive use of palm as hammer causes intimal damage, thrombosis, or aneurysm formation
Mechanics, carpenters, plumbers, butchers, machinists, cyclists (handlebar pressure), baseball catchers, martial artists - anyone using palm as striking surface
Ranges from intimal injury with thrombosis to frank aneurysm formation; thrombosis can propagate distally or embolize to digital arteries causing fingertip ischemia

Dominant hand affected; cold intolerance in ring and small fingers (ulnar distribution); digital cyanosis, pain, paresthesias; may present acutely with digital ischemia or chronically with Raynaud-like symptoms
Modified Allen test demonstrates incomplete palmar arch - ring and small fingers remain pale when ulnar artery occluded and radial released; digital pressure difference confirms diagnosis
Tender, pulsatile mass over hypothenar eminence (aneurysm); absent ulnar pulse at wrist; cool ring and small fingers; splinter hemorrhages or digital gangrene in severe cases
Duplex ultrasound shows thrombosis or aneurysm; CT or MR angiography for surgical planning; conventional angiography can be diagnostic and therapeutic (thrombolysis)

Conservative: activity modification, smoking cessation, calcium channel blockers for vasospasm, antiplatelet therapy. Surgical: resection with primary anastomosis, vein graft reconstruction, thrombolysis if acute
Digital ischemia threatening tissue loss, aneurysm at risk of rupture or embolization, failed conservative management with ongoing symptoms
Occupational modification - use proper tools instead of palm as hammer; padded gloves; handlebar modifications for cyclists

learning_objectives: Define hypothenar hammer syndrome and identify at-risk occupations
Understand the mechanism of ulnar artery injury at Guyon's canal
Use Allen test to diagnose incomplete palmar arch
Recognize ring and small finger symptoms as ulnar distribution
clinical_pearls: Think of this in manual laborers with ring/small finger ischemia
Abnormal Allen test (ulnar side remains pale) is key finding
Dominant hand + occupational use of palm as hammer = suspect HHS
Look for pulsatile mass over hypothenar eminence (aneurysm)
Cyclists can get this from handlebar pressure - not just laborers
Treatment ladder: activity modification → medical → surgical
common_mistakes: Diagnosing as primary Raynaud (check Allen test, look for aneurysm)
Treating symptomatically without addressing cause (activity modification)
